title: Anonymous lifetimes in impl trait are allowed in async fn, despite being an unstable feature

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: A-impl-trait
labels.description: Area: impl Trait. Universally / existentially quantified anonymous types with static dispatch.

body:
I tried this code ([playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=1f5e61ad851b4da09ba552c4268ac16d)):

```rust
async fn test(args: impl Iterator<Item = &str>) {}
```

I expected to see this happen: an error because `&str` contains an anonymous lifetime, and is part of an `impl Trait` type.

Instead, this happened: Compiles successfully.

Removing `async` from the function definition gives the following error (on nightly to see the feature gate):

```
error[E0658]: anonymous lifetimes in `impl Trait` are unstable
 --> src/lib.rs:1:37
  |
1 | fn test(args: impl Iterator<Item = &str>) {}
  |                                     ^ expected named lifetime parameter
  |
  = help: add `#![feature(anonymous_lifetime_in_impl_trait)]` to the crate attributes to enable
help: consider introducing a named lifetime parameter
  |
1 | fn test<'a>(args: impl Iterator<Item = &'a str>) {}
  |        ++++                             ++
```

This feature seems to have no documentation or tracking issue, only an [unstable book entry](https://dev-doc.rust-lang.org/stable/unstable-book/language-features/anonymous-lifetime-in-impl-trait.html#anonymous_lifetime_in_impl_trait). Given this, and the fact this behavior has been stable on async accidentally (AFAICT) for many releases now, maybe the best solution will be to just un-featuregate this functionality.

